doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: RISC-V RV32I 32-bit processor model

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: This Model is released under the Open Source Apache 2.0

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The model has the following architectural extensions enabled, and the following bits in the misa CSR Extensions field will be set upon reset:

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: misa bit 8: RV32I/RV64I/RV128I base integer instruction set

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: misa bit 18: extension S (Supervisor mode)

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: misa bit 20: extension U (User mode)

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: To specify features that can be dynamically enabled or disabled by writes to the misa register in addition to those listed above, use parameter "add_Extensions_mask". This is a string parameter containing the feature letters to add; for example, value "DV" indicates that double-precision floating point and the Vector Extension can be enabled or disabled by writes to the misa register, if supported on this variant.

doctext.name: txt_5
doctext.text: Legacy parameter "misa_Extensions_mask" can also be used. This Uns32-valued parameter specifies all writable bits in the misa Extensions field, replacing any permitted bits defined in the base variant.

doctext.name: txt_6
doctext.text: Note that any features that are indicated as present in the misa mask but absent in the misa will be ignored. See the next section.

docsection.name: doc_3
docsection.text: Available Extensions Not Enabled by Default

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The following extensions are supported by the model, but not enabled by default in this variant:

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: misa bit 0: extension A (atomic instructions)

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: misa bit 1: extension B (bit manipulation extension)

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: misa bit 2: extension C (compressed instructions)

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: misa bit 3: extension D (double-precision floating point)

doctext.name: txt_5
doctext.text: misa bit 4: RV32E base integer instruction set (embedded)

doctext.name: txt_6
doctext.text: misa bit 5: extension F (single-precision floating point)

doctext.name: txt_7
doctext.text: misa bit 7: extension H (hypervisor)

doctext.name: txt_8
doctext.text: misa bit 10: extension K (cryptographic)

doctext.name: txt_9
doctext.text: misa bit 12: extension M (integer multiply/divide instructions)

doctext.name: txt_10
doctext.text: misa bit 13: extension N (user-level interrupts)

doctext.name: txt_11
doctext.text: misa bit 21: extension V (vector extension)

doctext.name: txt_12
doctext.text: misa bit 23: extension X (non-standard extensions present)

doctext.name: txt_13
doctext.text: To add features from this list to the base variant, use parameter "add_Extensions". This is a string parameter containing the feature letters to add; for example, value "DV" indicates that double-precision floating point and the Vector Extension should be enabled, if they are currently absent and are available on this variant.

doctext.name: txt_14
doctext.text: Legacy parameter "misa_Extensions" can also be used. This Uns32-valued parameter specifies the reset value for the misa CSR Extensions field, replacing any permitted bits defined in the base variant.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: On this variant, the Machine trap-vector base-address register (mtvec) is writable. It can instead be configured as read-only using parameter "mtvec_is_ro".

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Values written to "mtvec" are masked using the value 0xfffffffd. A different mask of writable bits may be specified using parameter "mtvec_mask" if required. In addition, when Vectored interrupt mode is enabled, parameter "tvec_align" may be used to specify additional hardware-enforced base address alignment. In this variant, "tvec_align" defaults to 0, implying no alignment constraint.

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: The initial value of "mtvec" is 0x0. A different value may be specified using parameter "mtvec" if required.

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: Values written to "stvec" are masked using the value 0xfffffffd. A different mask of writable bits may be specified using parameter "stvec_mask" if required. parameter "tvec_align" may be used to specify additional hardware-enforced base address alignment in the same manner as for the "mtvec" register, described above.

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: On reset, the model will restart at address 0x0. A different reset address may be specified using parameter "reset_address" or applied using optional input port "reset_addr" if required.

doctext.name: txt_5
doctext.text: On an NMI, the model will restart at address 0x0. A different NMI address may be specified using parameter "nmi_address" or applied using optional input port "nmi_addr" if required.

doctext.name: txt_6
doctext.text: WFI will halt the processor until an interrupt occurs. It can instead be configured as a NOP using parameter "wfi_is_nop". WFI timeout wait is implemented with a time limit of 0 (i.e. WFI causes an Illegal Instruction trap in Supervisor mode when mstatus.TW=1).

doctext.name: txt_7
doctext.text: The "cycle" CSR is implemented in this variant. Set parameter "cycle_undefined" to True to instead specify that "cycle" is unimplemented and reads of it should trap to Machine mode.

doctext.name: txt_8
doctext.text: The "time" CSR is implemented in this variant. Set parameter "time_undefined" to True to instead specify that "time" is unimplemented and reads of it should trap to Machine mode. Usually, the value of the "time" CSR should be provided by the platform - see notes below about the artifact "CSR" bus for information about how this is done.

doctext.name: txt_9
doctext.text: The "instret" CSR is implemented in this variant. Set parameter "instret_undefined" to True to instead specify that "instret" is unimplemented and reads of it should trap to Machine mode.

doctext.name: txt_10
doctext.text: A 9-bit ASID is implemented. Use parameter "ASID_bits" to specify a different implemented ASID size if required.

doctext.name: txt_11
doctext.text: This variant supports address translation modes 0 and 1. Use parameter "Sv_modes" to specify a bit mask of different modes if required.

doctext.name: txt_12
doctext.text: TLB behavior is controlled by parameter "ASIDCacheSize". If this parameter is 0, then an unlimited number of TLB entries will be maintained concurrently. If this parameter is non-zero, then only TLB entries for up to "ASIDCacheSize" different ASIDs will be maintained concurrently initially; as new ASIDs are used, TLB entries for less-recently used ASIDs are deleted, which improves model performance in some cases. If the model detects that the TLB entry cache is too small (entry ejections are very frequent), it will increase the cache size automatically. In this variant, "ASIDCacheSize" is 8

doctext.name: txt_13
doctext.text: Unaligned memory accesses are not supported by this variant. Set parameter "unaligned" to "T" to enable such accesses.

doctext.name: txt_14
doctext.text: 16 PMP entries are implemented by this variant. Use parameter "PMP_registers" to specify a different number of PMP entries; set the parameter to 0 to disable the PMP unit. The PMP grain size (G) is 0, meaning that PMP regions as small as 4 bytes are implemented. Use parameter "PMP_grain" to specify a different grain size if required. Unaligned PMP accesses are not decomposed into separate aligned accesses; use parameter "PMP_decompose" to modify this behavior if required.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The model can be configured to implement a Core Local Interrupt Controller (CLIC) using parameter "CLICLEVELS"; when non-zero, the CLIC is present with the specified number of interrupt levels (2-256), as described in the RISC-V Core-Local Interrupt Controller specification, and further parameters are made available to configure other aspects of the CLIC. "CLICLEVELS" is zero in this variant, indicating that a CLIC is not implemented.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The "reset" port is an active-high reset input. The processor is halted when "reset" goes high and resumes execution from the reset address specified using the "reset_address" parameter or "reset_addr" port when the signal goes low. The "mcause" register is cleared to zero.

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: The "nmi" port is an active-high NMI input. The processor resumes execution from the address specified using the "nmi_address" parameter or "nmi_addr" port when the NMI signal goes high. The "mcause" register is cleared to zero.

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: All other interrupt ports are active high. For each implemented privileged execution level, there are by default input ports for software interrupt, timer interrupt and external interrupt; for example, for Machine mode, these are called "MSWInterrupt", "MTimerInterrupt" and "MExternalInterrupt", respectively. When the N extension is implemented, ports are also present for User mode. Parameter "unimp_int_mask" allows the default behavior to be changed to exclude certain interrupt ports. The parameter value is a mask in the same format as the "mip" CSR; any interrupt corresponding to a non-zero bit in this mask will be removed from the processor and read as zero in "mip", "mie" and "mideleg" CSRs (and Supervisor and User mode equivalents if implemented).

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: Parameter "external_int_id" can be used to enable extra interrupt ID input ports on each hart. If the parameter is True then when an external interrupt is applied the value on the ID port is sampled and used to fill the Exception Code field in the "mcause" CSR (or the equivalent CSR for other execution levels). For Machine mode, the extra interrupt ID port is called "MExternalInterruptID".

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: The "deferint" port is an active-high artifact input that, when written to 1, prevents any pending-and-enabled interrupt being taken (normally, such an interrupt would be taken on the next instruction after it becomes pending-and-enabled). The purpose of this signal is to enable alignment with hardware models in step-and-compare usage.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The model can be configured to implement Debug mode using parameter "debug_mode". This implements features described in Chapter 4 of the RISC-V External Debug Support specification with version specified by parameter "debug_version" (see References). Some aspects of this mode are not defined in the specification because they are implementation-specific; the model provides infrastructure to allow implementation of a Debug Module using a custom harness. Features added are described below.

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Parameter "debug_mode" can be used to specify three different behaviors, as follows:

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: 1. If set to value "vector", then operations that would cause entry to Debug mode result in the processor jumping to the address specified by the "debug_address" parameter. It will execute at this address, in Debug mode, until a "dret" instruction causes return to non-Debug mode. Any exception generated during this execution will cause a jump to the address specified by the "dexc_address" parameter.

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: 2. If set to value "interrupt", then operations that would cause entry to Debug mode result in the processor simulation call (e.g. opProcessorSimulate) returning, with a stop reason of OP_SR_INTERRUPT. In this usage scenario, the Debug Module is implemented in the simulation harness.

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: 3. If set to value "halt", then operations that would cause entry to Debug mode result in the processor halting. Depending on the simulation environment, this might cause a return from the simulation call with a stop reason of OP_SR_HALT, or debug mode might be implemented by another platform component which then restarts the debugged processor again.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The specification does not define how Debug mode is implemented. In this model, Debug mode is enabled by a Boolean pseudo-register, "DM". When "DM" is True, the processor is in Debug mode. When "DM" is False, mode is defined by "mstatus" in the usual way.

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Entry to Debug mode can be performed in any of these ways:

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: 1. By writing True to register "DM" (e.g. using opProcessorRegWrite) followed by simulation of at least one cycle (e.g. using opProcessorSimulate), dcsr cause will be reported as trigger;

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: 2. By writing a 1 then 0 to net "haltreq" (using opNetWrite) followed by simulation of at least one cycle (e.g. using opProcessorSimulate);

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: 3. By writing a 1 to net "resethaltreq" (using opNetWrite) while the "reset" signal undergoes a negedge transition, followed by simulation of at least one cycle (e.g. using opProcessorSimulate);

doctext.name: txt_5
doctext.text: 4. By executing an "ebreak" instruction when Debug mode entry for the current processor mode is enabled by dcsr.ebreakm, dcsr.ebreaks or dcsr.ebreaku.

doctext.name: txt_6
doctext.text: In all cases, the processor will save required state in "dpc" and "dcsr" and then perform actions described above, depending in the value of the "debug_mode" parameter.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Exit from Debug mode can be performed in any of these ways:

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: 1. By writing False to register "DM" (e.g. using opProcessorRegWrite) followed by simulation of at least one cycle (e.g. using opProcessorSimulate);

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: 2. By executing an "dret" instruction when Debug mode.

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: In both cases, the processor will perform the steps described in section 4.6 (Resume) of the Debug specification.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: When Debug mode is enabled, registers "dcsr", "dpc", "dscratch0" and "dscratch1" are implemented as described in the specification. These may be manipulated externally by a Debug Module using opProcessorRegRead or opProcessorRegWrite; for example, the Debug Module could write "dcsr" to enable "ebreak" instruction behavior as described above, or read and write "dpc" to emulate stepping over an "ebreak" instruction prior to resumption from Debug mode.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The specification allows execution of code fragments in Debug mode. A Debug Module implementation can cause execution in Debug mode by the following steps:

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: 1. Write the address of a Program Buffer to the program counter using opProcessorPCSet;

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: 2. If "debug_mode" is set to "halt", write 0 to pseudo-register "DMStall" (to leave halted state);

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: 3. If entry to Debug mode was handled by exiting the simulation callback, call opProcessorSimulate or opRootModuleSimulate to resume simulation.

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: Debug mode will be re-entered in these cases:

doctext.name: txt_5
doctext.text: 1. By execution of an "ebreak" instruction; or:

doctext.name: txt_6
doctext.text: 2. By execution of an instruction that causes an exception.

doctext.name: txt_7
doctext.text: In both cases, the processor will either jump to the debug exception address, or return control immediately to the harness, with stopReason of OP_SR_INTERRUPT, or perform a halt, depending on the value of the "debug_mode" parameter.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: When in Debug mode, the processor or harness can cause a single instruction to be executed on return from that mode by setting dcsr.step. After one non-Debug-mode instruction has been executed, control will be returned to the harness. The processor will remain in single-step mode until dcsr.step is cleared.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Port "DM" is an output signal that indicates whether the processor is in Debug mode

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Port "haltreq" is a rising-edge-triggered signal that triggers entry to Debug mode (see above).

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: Port "resethaltreq" is a level-sensitive signal that triggers entry to Debug mode after reset (see above).

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: This model is configured with a trigger module, implementing a subset of the behavior described in Chapter 5 of the RISC-V External Debug Support specification with version specified by parameter "debug_version" (see References).

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The model currently supports tdata1 of type 0, type 2 (mcontrol), type 3 (icount), type 4 (itrigger), type 5 (etrigger) and type 6 (mcontrol6). icount triggers are implemented for a single instruction only, with count hard-wired to 1 and automatic zeroing of mode bits when the trigger fires.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Parameter "trigger_num" is used to specify the number of implemented triggers. In this variant, "trigger_num" is 4.

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Parameter "tinfo" is used to specify the value of the read-only "tinfo" register, which indicates the trigger types supported. In this variant, "tinfo" is 0x7d.

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: Parameter "tinfo_undefined" is used to specify whether the "tinfo" register is undefined, in which case reads of it trap to Machine mode. In this variant, "tinfo_undefined" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: Parameter "tcontrol_undefined" is used to specify whether the "tcontrol" register is undefined, in which case accesses to it trap to Machine mode. In this variant, "tcontrol_undefined" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: Parameter "mcontext_undefined" is used to specify whether the "mcontext" register is undefined, in which case accesses to it trap to Machine mode. In this variant, "mcontext_undefined" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_5
doctext.text: Parameter "scontext_undefined" is used to specify whether the "scontext" register is undefined, in which case accesses to it trap to Machine mode. In this variant, "scontext_undefined" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_6
doctext.text: Parameter "mscontext_undefined" is used to specify whether the "mscontext" register is undefined, in which case accesses to it trap to Machine mode. In this variant, "mscontext_undefined" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_7
doctext.text: Parameter "amo_trigger" is used to specify whether load/store triggers are activated for AMO instructions. In this variant, "amo_trigger" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_8
doctext.text: Parameter "no_hit" is used to specify whether the "hit" bit in tdata1 is unimplemented. In this variant, "no_hit" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_9
doctext.text: Parameter "no_sselect_2" is used to specify whether the "sselect" field in "textra32"/"textra64" registers is unable to hold value 2 (indicating match by ASID is not allowed). In this variant, "no_sselect_2" is 0.

doctext.name: txt_10
doctext.text: Parameter "mcontext_bits" is used to specify the number of writable bits in the "mcontext" register. In this variant, "mcontext_bits" is 6.

doctext.name: txt_11
doctext.text: Parameter "scontext_bits" is used to specify the number of writable bits in the "scontext" register. In this variant, "scontext_bits" is 16.

doctext.name: txt_12
doctext.text: Parameter "mvalue_bits" is used to specify the number of writable bits in the "mvalue" field in "textra32"/"textra64" registers; if zero, the "mselect" field is tied to zero. In this variant, "mvalue_bits" is 6.

doctext.name: txt_13
doctext.text: Parameter "svalue_bits" is used to specify the number of writable bits in the "svalue" field in "textra32"/"textra64" registers; if zero, the "sselect" is tied to zero. In this variant, "svalue_bits" is 16.

doctext.name: txt_14
doctext.text: Parameter "mcontrol_maskmax" is used to specify the value of field "maskmax" in the "mcontrol" register. In this variant, "mcontrol_maskmax" is 63.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: It is possible to enable model debug messages in various categories. This can be done statically using the "override_debugMask" parameter, or dynamically using the "debugflags" command. Enabled messages are specified using a bitmask value, as follows:

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Value 0x002: enable debugging of PMP and virtual memory state;

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: Value 0x004: enable debugging of interrupt state.

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: All other bits in the debug bitmask are reserved and must not be set to non-zero values.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: This model implements a number of non-architectural pseudo-registers and other features to facilitate integration.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: If parameter "enable_CSR_bus" is True, an artifact 16-bit bus "CSR" is enabled. Slave callbacks installed on this bus can be used to implement modified CSR behavior (use opBusSlaveNew or icmMapExternalMemory, depending on the client API). A CSR with index 0xABC is mapped on the bus at address 0xABC0; as a concrete example, implementing CSR "time" (number 0xC01) externally requires installation of callbacks at address 0xC010 on the CSR bus.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Instruction pipelines are not modeled in any way. All instructions are assumed to complete immediately. This means that instruction barrier instructions (e.g. fence.i) are treated as NOPs, with the exception of any Illegal Instruction behavior, which is modeled.

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Caches and write buffers are not modeled in any way. All loads, fetches and stores complete immediately and in order, and are fully synchronous. Data barrier instructions (e.g. fence) are treated as NOPs, with the exception of any Illegal Instruction behavior, which is modeled.

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: Real-world timing effects are not modeled: all instructions are assumed to complete in a single cycle.

doctext.name: txt_3
doctext.text: Hardware Performance Monitor registers are not implemented and hardwired to zero.

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: The TLB is architecturally-accurate but not device accurate. This means that all TLB maintenance and address translation operations are fully implemented but the cache is larger than in the real device.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: All instructions have been extensively tested by Imperas, using tests generated specifically for this model and also reference tests from https://github.com/riscv/riscv-tests.

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: Also reference tests have been used from various sources including:

doctext.name: txt_4
doctext.text: The Imperas OVPsim RISC-V models are used in the RISC-V Foundation Compliance Framework as a functional Golden Reference:

doctext.name: txt_6
doctext.text: where the simulated model is used to provide the reference signatures for compliance testing. The Imperas OVPsim RISC-V models are used as reference in both open source and commercial instruction stream test generators for hardware design verification, for example:

doctext.name: txt_7
doctext.text: http://valtrix.in/sting from Valtrix

doctext.name: txt_8
doctext.text: https://github.com/google/riscv-dv from Google

doctext.name: txt_9
doctext.text: The Imperas OVPsim RISC-V models are also used by commercial and open source RISC-V Core RTL developers as a reference to ensure correct functionality of their IP.

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: The Model details are based upon the following specifications:

doctext.name: txt_1
doctext.text: RISC-V Instruction Set Manual, Volume I: User-Level ISA (User Architecture Version 20190305-Base-Ratification)

doctext.name: txt_2
doctext.text: RISC-V Instruction Set Manual, Volume II: Privileged Architecture (Privileged Architecture Version 20190405-Priv-MSU-Ratification)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Selects variant (either a generic UISA or a specific model)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify required User Architecture version

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: User Architecture Version 2.2

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Deprecated and equivalent to 20190305

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: User Architecture Version 20190305-Base-Ratification

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify required Privileged Architecture version

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Privileged Architecture Version 1.10

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Deprecated and equivalent to 20190405

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Privileged Architecture Version 20190405-Priv-MSU-Ratification

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Privileged Architecture Master Branch (1.12 draft)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify required Debug Architecture version

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: RISC-V External Debug Support Version 0.13.2-DRAFT

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: RISC-V External Debug Support Version 0.14.0-DRAFT

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify how Debug mode is implemented

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Debug mode not implemented

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Debug mode implemented by execution at vector

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Debug mode implemented by interrupt

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Debug mode implemented by halt

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify verbose output messages

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of hart contexts in a multiprocessor

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether hardware update of PTE A bit is supported

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether hardware update of PTE D bit is supported

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether the processor supports unaligned memory accesses

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether WFI should be treated as a NOP (if not, halt while waiting for interrupts)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether mtvec CSR is read-only

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify hardware-enforced alignment of mtvec/stvec/utvec when Vectored interrupt mode enabled

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify hardware-enforced mask of writable bits in mcounteren/scounteren registers

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify hardware-enforced mask of always-zero bits in mcountinhibit register

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify hardware-enforced mask of writable bits in mtvec register

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify hardware-enforced mask of writable bits in stvec register

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify hardware-enforced mask of writable bits in xcause.ExceptionCode

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify xcause.ExceptionCode for NMI

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether mtval/stval/utval are hard wired to zero

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether mtval/stval/utval are set to zero by an ebreak

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether mtval/stval contain faulting instruction bits on illegal instruction exception

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the cycle CSR is undefined (reads to it are emulated by a Machine mode trap)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the time CSR is undefined (reads to it are emulated by a Machine mode trap)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the instret CSR is undefined (reads to it are emulated by a Machine mode trap)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the tinfo CSR is undefined

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the tcontrol CSR is undefined

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the mcontext CSR is undefined

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the scontext CSR is undefined

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that the mscontext CSR is undefined (Debug Version 0.14.0 and later)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify whether AMO load/store operations activate triggers

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that tdata1.hit is unimplemented

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that textra.sselect=2 is not supported (no trigger match by ASID)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Add artifact CSR bus port, allowing CSR registers to be externally implemented

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Comma-separated list of CSR number mappings, each of the form <csrName>=<number>

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Whether an xRET instruction preserves the value of LR

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specifies the number of different ASIDs for which TLB entries are cached; a value of 0 implies no limit

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of implemented hardware triggers

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override tinfo register (for all triggers)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of implemented bits in mcontext

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of implemented bits in scontext

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of implemented bits in textra.mvalue (if zero, textra.mselect is tied to zero)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of implemented bits in textra.svalue (if zero, textra.sselect is tied to zero)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify mcontrol.maskmax value

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of implemented ASID bits

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override reset vector address

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override NMI vector address

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify PMP region granularity, G (0 => 4 bytes, 1 => 8 bytes, etc)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the number of implemented PMP address registers

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify the maximum size of PMP region to map if non-zero (may improve performance; constrained to a power of two)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Whether unaligned PMP accesses are decomposed into separate aligned accesses

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify bit mask of implemented Sv modes (e.g. 1<<8 is Sv39)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify number of supplemental local interrupts

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify mask of unimplemented interrupts (e.g. 1<<9 indicates Supervisor external interrupt unimplemented)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify mask of interrupts always delegated to lower-priority execution level from Machine execution level

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify mask of interrupts always delegated to User execution level from Supervisor execution level

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify mask of interrupts that cannot be delegated to lower-priority execution levels

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify mask of exceptions that cannot be delegated to lower-priority execution levels

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Whether to add nets allowing External Interrupt ID codes to be forced

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that data endianness is fixed (mstatus.{MBE,SBE,UBE} fields are read-only)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override default value of misa.MXL

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override default value of misa.Extensions

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Add extensions specified by letters to misa.Extensions (for example, specify "VD" to add V and D features)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override mask of writable bits in misa.Extensions

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Add extensions specified by letters to mask of writable bits in misa.Extensions (for example, specify "VD" to add V and D features)

doctext.text: Override mvendorid register

doctext.text: Override marchid register

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override mimpid register

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override mhartid register (or first mhartid of an incrementing sequence if this is an SMP variant)

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Override mtvec register

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify that mstatus.FS is hard-wired to zero

doctext.name: txt
doctext.text: Specify number of interrupt levels implemented by CLIC, or 0 if CLIC absent
